subject: Re: [junit] Article on a testing pattern
msgSnippet: I think it is important for at least the test methods to be untouchable , especially if you are releasing the Abstract Test to unknown users.  Making setUp
messageBody:
I think it is important for at least the test methods to be
"untouchable", especially if you are releasing the Abstract Test to
unknown users. Making setUp and tearDown final is not quite as
important to me, as long as they get run. You could let the Concrete
Tests override them but you would have to have a way to ensure that the
overriden versions call super(). You could use set a flag in the
abstract test's setUp and then fail if you don't see the flag at the
beginning of each test.

I have actually been using the createXXX abstract method to do any
initialization specific to the Concrete Test. Sometimes that looks a
little clumsy to me, so using a non-final setUp method may be the better
long term solution.

On Wed, 2002-02-06 at 10:12, Francois Beausoleil wrote:
Hello Eric,

I have been doing something similar. I had not thought about making setUp(),
tearDown() and the tests final though. I agree that this is a very good idea.
Now, you only have to provide a Template Method so that subclasses of the
abstract test can do their own initialization.

Have a nice day !
Francois Beausoleil

> I have written an article in which I describe a Testing Pattern which
> I call AbstractTest. The basic idea is to maximize reuse of tests
> written for an interface for every implementation of the interface.
>
> I have been using this technique for a while to good effect, but I would
> love to to get some feedback from this group on the issue. I am
> especially interested to hear about other approaches that people have
> used to accomplish the same goals.
